pubStmt.avail:
THIS TEXT IS AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE WORLD only as part of the British National Corpus at nominal charge FOR ACADEMIC RESEARCH PURPOSES SUBJECT TO A SIGNED END USER LICENCE HAVING BEEN RECEIVED BY OXFORD UNIVERSITY COMPUTING SERVICES, from whom forms and supporting materials are available.
THIS TEXT IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR COMMERCIAL RESEARCH AND EXPLOITATION unless terms have first been agreed with the BNC Consortium Exploitation Committee. Apply in the first instance to Oxford University Computing Services.
It is your responsibility, as a user, to ensure that an End User Licence is in place. For your information, the Terms of the End User Licence are set out in the corpus header, which is likely to have a file name similar to "corphdr" or "CORPHDR".
Distribution of any part of the corpus under the terms of the Licence must include a copy of the corpus header. Distribution of this corpus text under the terms of the Licence must include this header embodying this notice.
THE EXACT CONDITIONS OF USE FOR THIS TEXT ARE NOT CURRENTLY KNOWN TO THE ARCHIVING AGENCY. PLEASE CONTACT THE DATA CAPTURE AGENCY NAMED IN THIS HEADER FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.

encDesc.projDesc: See the project description in the corpus header for information about the British National Corpus project.
encDesc.refsDecl: Canonical references in the British National Corpus are to text segment (<s>) elements, and are constructed by taking the value of the n attribute of the <cdif> element containing the target text, and concatenating a dot separator, followed by the value of the n attribute of the target <s> element.

respStmt.resp: Amendments for initial release of sampler
respStmt.name: dominic

s.w: Are you staying in all day today?
Erm, cos I've got to go down to Horley I 've got to go to the bank.
Yeah I've got a lot of English prep to do.
Yes, O K well I'm going to er I've got lots of work to do before I can go.
I shan't be going until about lunch time.

pause.w: I'll leave it to you, to your prep then.

s.w: Ah how's the old prep going eh?
Oh you've finished it, oh good.

pause.w: Alright?

s.w: Well I hope you get on well with what you're doing for your scenery.
Cos in York, or Yorkshire, they have those as starters with gravy.
You just have those in a big bowl of gravy.
We went, when we were staying in York, we went to erm used to go to a pub for our meals didn't we?
And erm I've seen these at ten o'clock at night you know people come in and have a bowl of sort of soup, and, well I suppose it's gravy in there.
And I tried it one night, it was very yummy and very filling.

pause.w: Oh my god I don't like doing this.

s.w: And I don't like this weather.
Sometimes it's colder indoors than out actually, isn't it?
It's gone on, well it is if the sun's out, and you know if the sun's out.
You want your health in the summer.

pause.w: I don't remember this before.

s.w: Oh yes they are, I've got all
Well move up a bit this way Fred if you don't mind.
I don't know why I've not noticed it before.
It's got four legs on it.
Well, why don't you start helping yourself
Well who the hell put an empty horseradish pot back in the cupboard?
Well I thought I'd put horseradish on the whatsit one week.

ptr.w: Yes fetching a spoon or two

pause.w: oh you're doing a grand job there.

s.w: Oh you've made a mistake here John.
We haven't had roast beef for ages.
If you want to get yourself a drink, Alex, do.

ptr.w: Do you want white wine Mum?

s.w: The special touch, you might say .

vocal.w: Are these the ones you put in when we went out?

s.w: They really ought to have got moved down to the bottom.
I find it's very difficult in these ovens to, you know a normal oven you could sort of put things to the bottom that you've already done .

ptr.w: Well you can't these, can you?

s.w: you can in mine cos mine's, mine's
Yes but then you still have heat coming from the and the top, top and the bottom don't you?
Then you've got the top's a grill as well so that
you can get two places that are hot, and on top it's absolutely
Yes, if I'm not using the grill I take it out.
It would take a long time to get our grill out because I don't think it would move any more.
Can somebody pass me the new potatoes please?
Hang on I'll move this one.

pause.w: Thank you very much.
Could you, erm, spear me a roasty

s.w: A roasty, a very roasty, or a medium roasty?

pause.w: Thank you.

s.w: Did you find another horseradish thing, did you?
Oh, I give it, is that horseradish?
I'll, I'll, I'll have some er
Mum, do you want some of this?
No, I've got mustard thank you John.
I want a bit more horseradish
Oh well, I'll, I'll have a bit of horseradish when I've mustard off.
The only problem is it's only worth buying if you're buying a reasonable sized piece.
Can't really buy a small piece.
Is this the same as a wing rib?
Well I'd call it fore rib.
Then you've got little ribs after that.
Do you have it, erm sort of boned?
Well I used to this was two ribs.
That's what fore rib's the small one.

pause.w: The other rib, of beef I mean, to get a piece that's worth cooking cos to carve it and everything else you need at least three ribs and the ribs are sort of usually it's about that sort of size

s.w: and you're talking about a piece at least about eight, seventeen, eighteen pounds.
There's so much fat in the gravy.
Yes this beef's come out very well hasn't it?
It's not maybe as rare as you ought to have it but it really tastes nice.

pause.w: With disasters and all it's come out reasonably well at the end of the day.

s.w: Well you've created something rather nice out of your disaster then.
The cornflour packet didn't have much left in it.
It's got too much fat in it.
I didn't think it had got enough.
Well I never put salt and pepper in my gravy so
I use cornflour and two Oxos.
If I'm then doing things, if I'm doing beef gravy I put the beef stock cube, and either one or two Oxos to
And then add all the juices from the meat.
But I don't add anything else.
I never put salt and pepper in my gravy, I never have done.
That's what I like, like about mum's gravy.
But I always add all the juices from the meat.
Out of the meat tin and
How did you do this gravy then dad?
No, you've got Bovril, you've got, erm, Oxos some garlic and pepper and some cornflour and then your mother had to lob in some, something else.
Because we'd run out of cornflour and it was all not thick enough.
Your use of the English language in front of the microphone is extremely
It's lucky I don't talk to a microphone very often.

unclear.w: a microphone over there, dad, and it's turned on.

s.w: So I don't think it matters.

unclear.w: they don't know who your dad is.

s.w: They know whose household this is.
They know this is the household.
Yeah, but they do now that it's the household.
Can I have some more Yorkshire puddings please, daddy?
Half a one or so I suppose.
Well Alex mixed the mix, I put them in the oven and Sue told me get them out or they'll burn.
So it was a sort of a three way erm
They were only burning because you put in what was written on the packet.
Well what's written on the packet is correct unless you have the grill not exactly red hot but about three eighty five.
Twenty five minutes isn't a bad time
Oh I never cook them for twenty, twenty to twenty five minutes it would be a disaster.
I was going to say, do you cook Alexander?

unclear.w: Chinese meal the other day, didn't you?

s.w: What stir fry and all that stuff?

ptr.w: sauces, soy sauces and things like that.

s.w: It was braised prawns er we had erm lamb, marinated lamb bits with erm erm garlic and cinnamon as well

pause.w: And we had erm chicken noodles with bamboo shoots.

s.w: We were going to do rice but there was
What, did you do all this did you?
I did most of the preparation, Mum looked after what was cooking.
It's the preparation that takes so long in Chinese cooking.
Well there's so many different bits to it isn't there?
When I do a Chinese meal
There's so many bits of sauce and

ptr.w: I spent about two hours measuring out all the different things.

s.w: Then I put labels on about every single pot I could find that's got all these various mixes in.
And I've got sort of like sweet and sour with prawns sort of er raising mix for something else.
That's what I don't like with Chinese, erm, everything's so complicated.
You just shove everything in a pan.
Do you go out to restaurants for a Chinese meal

ptr.w: That's what, you know when I did that er Chinese bolognese thing.

s.w: Do you remember when I did that Chinese bolognese thing?
I made half of that up.
But I got the main thing off a, off a T V programme.
But I couldn't get, I didn't get it all down.
So you made up the rest?
So I made up the rest and everyone liked it.
You actually need a bigger kitchen to cook Chinese.
Because you need to set everything out.
Like I did, when I did it I just
put it back well I put it back, got that, put a bit of that in.
Put a bit of everything in apart from the vegetables which I knew what to put in.
I don't think you'd like me doing that Alex?
You complain as it is about the number of dishes I use.
I could imagine if I did Chinese

ptr.w: I don't use that many dishes when I do Chinese.
We have the same argument in this household.

s.w: Well I can use one bowl, but I don't I use two.

ptr.w: Never use five bowls if one will do.

s.w: When it's like pancake mix I tend, or omelettes I tend to use two bowls and even though I only really need to use one.
Do you want some more white wine mum?
Erm, a wee bit then, thank you.
What time do you have to go back to school Alexander?
Do you mind sitting down till you've erm finished, old chap.
They're all clean in there then.
Do you want warm bread pudding?
Just because it's not warm it doesn't mean you can't have custard with it.
At school we have cold pudding with custard.
then I'll have to wash a saucepan.
Oh dear, you won't like that Alexander.
It's not very difficult, you've got one that you've done carrots in.
Just have a quick slosh, well hardly even needs a slosh round does it?
You don't have to tell them.
It's got, there'll be a carrot flavouring in it.
You hate carrot cake or whatever it is.
Sorry I just ripped all the buttons off me shirt.
Do you really think I'd rip the buttons of me shirt?

pause.w: There you go.

s.w: Oh, it's nice and sunny out.
And as soon as we finish it'll go and get dark again.
Well don't worry dear it won't matter to you what the weather's like for the next week will it?
I've got to do javelin and I don't like going down there in the wet.
When have you got to do javelin?
But you've got all your revision to do.
I also have a games lesson Tuesday and Thursday mum.
I also have an extremely important athletics meeting on Saturday.
We ought to be coming to see that.
They go at the senior school
He doesn't know where it is.
They don't go at se with the senior schools.
What's this your thing on Saturday Alex?
No, they er I heard someone say that though they sort of actively encourage the use of to go to see many things like sort of sport days, erm .

pause.w: The main school has a much better sports day though.

s.w: They have it after speech day.
So they have half a speech day
They have speech day on the Saturday morning that the ball is on.
Did you have a good nosh?
It wasn't boring but it was, just, I mean you know they're sitting five hundred people all at one go and it's
It wasn't a boring night though.
They get fifteen thousand pounds and they don't make anything from it.

ptr.w: But it wasn't boring to watch though mum.

s.w: But I'm sure if they were the organizers entirely organized.

ptr.w: But I'm sure if they could make a profit they would.

s.w: Why did you get out of it?

ptr.w: Don't make too much custard Alexander, cos I'll.

s.w: I just went to Mike and Rob 's house and my friends.
And we just mucked about until four in the morning.
They just mucked about until four in the morning.
By which time we were all fast asleep in our little beds.
You came home at four in the morning.
I was home here in bed and asleep at half past three.
And I can vouch for that.
We didn't get to sleep until about three then.
That was the night I couldn't sleep
We got to sleep what, about an hour after you went.
after you got, after you got to erm
I know what time you went to sleep because Rob's dad came in, or his mum hammered on the door and said cut it out lads, go to sleep.
Oh that must have been when I smacked my nose on my Walkman.
He stayed at Bob's house, Rob's.
Cos he lives about a quarter of a mile away from the school.
He says, what is he, second row prop Alexander?
No he's not he's a hooker.

unclear.w: had carrots in your er Right dad?

s.w: Help you see in the dark.

ptr.w: How do they go on in the senior school.

s.w: Do they still have the under fourteens, under fifteens?
But then, the, Alex thinks there's a whole lot more boys joining, joining the school.
What would you do if I set fire to the new, to the shirt?
It does seem a shame to leave
Who was going to have that?
It's too late now I've got .
I wasn't going to have it.
The next time I see you you'll be saying why did I eat all that
Where are you going with it?
You all know who he takes after don't you?
Mum I've that thing with a hole in it.

pause.w: Stop.

unclear.w: see if it's still going round.

s.w: It's a thing with a hole in it.
Don't use that for a creme caramel.
That's what you said you were going to use.
I thought I had a mould.
That, that, that was sort of
That thing will always be a slug now won't it?
I can't remember ever, have you the name?
Sort of a er orangy chocolate mousse.
But it was only because it was done in er er I think.
What's the chart up on the board?
But he uses, uses it for everything you know.
It's all in, I mean the days are down from the top to the bottom.
It goes along for twelve months.
And the days go down and I think that there's numbers at the bottom.
I was waiting for somebody to pass the creme caramel out of the fridge.
There we are knowing my luck it won't come out.
Do you have to dip it in hot water or something?
Well no it's creme caramel, is that

unclear.w: creme caramel or proper creme caramel?

s.w: You're not supposed to ask those sort of questions dad.
No it's only because we made some on holiday when we went to
Some man, he said oh, he made it all sort of proper.
Oh I can make it all proper.
Not that you haven't done it
You know instead of tipping it over which would probably help I'd put that

ptr.w: put that on top and put the two over together.

s.w: Not hard enough to break the dish
Yes I do think you need to why don't you just try dishing it up out of the thing?
You're never going to get that out.

pause.w: All you've got to do is get rid of the air.

s.w: Oh clever dick, oh the clever trousers.

pause.w: Creme caramel and custard.

s.w: You've had it for a few years too.
You're not supposed to make lumpy custard.
You make very very good custard normally.
You've made lumpy custard you can eat it.

pause.w: I don't know what happened.

s.w: No, I'm just putting some so if it all ends up thrown away

unclear.w: get thrown away always ends up getting thrown away.

ptr.w: It goes in the fridge for about four days.

s.w: No it doesn't I jack it out sometimes.
I throw it away straight away these days.
Oh John that is such a terrible waste.
Well what, what are you going to do with it?
It's making too much to start with.
I'll make myself some cauliflower cheese tomorrow morning.
Why don't you just cut it all up and put a curry sauce over it?
I'll have cauliflower cheese tomorrow er lunchtime.

ptr.w: The rest you can fry up in the evening and have it with your cold beef.

s.w: Can somebody pass me a towel please?

ptr.w: Yes but you see when you get out of here about seven times between half past six and eight o'clock at night

s.w: Well you ha at least haven't got to do vegetables have you?
I mean they're already done for you.
Just reheat those and you're off and away.

pause.w: I like to have a lot of vegetables left over.

s.w: I can have them fried the next day.
What will we do with it?
Well generally there's, there's only three of us here
I said does anybody like it.
Did I actually say the words does anybody
I I said does anybody like lumpy custard.
Does that mean that I've made lumpy custard?

ptr.w: Well no you didn't actually say but one would presume from that that that's what you were getting.

s.w: What you should have said is I hope everybody likes lumpy custard.
Well the trouble with making it in a jar is you don't get much skin do you?
If you put it in a basin then you can sort of
Yeah but the sk skin's thicker.

unclear.w: mum's done it in a sweater then it

s.w: Should have slipped it in the erm in the oven.
You nearly said the microwave didn't you?
I nearly said the microwave, but in the oven.
The other thing's behind next to the erm scales.
Er how did you manage to get two sides of that so perfectly straight?
Well I'll get the cream out.
Oh yes it was in thing.
I'll divide it up between three of us.

unclear.w: other erm thing, whatever it is.

s.w: Oh it's your bread pudding, I see.
I made one yesterday in a meat tin and so Lynn had a lump and I got a lump and you here.
Would anybody like some of this?
We've got four, four puddings here aren't there?
I'd like a piece of Gran's thing to start with.

pause.w: I'll have some of that.

s.w: Well that's not fair Alexander is it?
Your mother said who wants what.
Alexander said and Fred got served first.
She was trying to get rid of this that's why.
Young people have got to stand up for their rights Alexander.
Oh yeah I'll get the cream.
I mean I read according to the paper this morning young people have got to have a

unclear.w: elders and betters and all that.

s.w: Young people have got to what?
Stand up to their, have a say.
Ah, since when does nobody listen to you?
I'll have a piece of that please.

pause.w: Nobody will want custard

s.w: I know but but eat custard with meringue.
It makes the meringue go all weird.
No I'll have some of that please.
I'll have some of that too please.
I'll have some of nan's bread pudding I think. .

unclear.w: ought to do is to eat the things that he's saying that nobody wants.

s.w: They're just trying to prove you
What are you going to have nan?
I'm going to have some cream please.
They don't have a lot of that there.
Have a lot of what left?

ptr.w: I don't, no I haven't, I don't worry about it.

s.w: I'll save the rest of it for you.
No I've come to the conclusion that we're deprived these days.
We don't have any sweets much.
When people come but otherwise we're deprived.
There was me thinking that you always.

ptr.w: We had this really nice Danish apple bar that I did last night.

pause.w: The pastry is a little crispy but

s.w: I haven't had a jelly for ages and I got one from Sainsbury's.
And I actually did it in a plastic basin.
And it has stained it so badly.
And I think well what do they put in this type of thing and it really wasn't that good was it?
I don't know the things you eat with that much colouring in it erm
No, it wasn't a proper jelly bowl.

unclear.w: jelly bowl or my jelly bowl .

s.w: That's another thing you can't get now is very much is chocolate blancmange.
Yes we have we've got some chocolate ones.

pause.w: How do you make then?

s.w: That's chocolate and erm, you melt the chocolate and an orange jelly.
Some blinking thing they're, they're needing for a er accents you know
Some sort of weird gross lumpy custard, very nice.
We, we haven't got accents as such have we?
Oh, well we have but it's a London

ptr.w: I don't think you well a month now, I mean cotton is a natural .

s.w: Yeah that's right but I mean we're just a south east London
Well I, I would call it south London.
It's certainly not a north London accent.
The north London accent is exactly the same I used to live there for years.
Well I lived in north east London.
Well it depends where you're, where you're going .
What's that treacle thing that we got from you the other day?
That had to be kept in the fridge .
I just wondered whether it was
It was in the fridge and the dog.
It was, it was very nice except that Fred had a piece and left the last couple of slices in the tin on the side and the dog took a shine to it so it was in a tin and then in the dog.

unclear.w: you can't blame the dog for that.

s.w: Well as far as I'm concerned it was the dog on the side.

pause.w: I don't know why I don't eat it more often.

unclear.w: caramel it was sort of sludge.

s.w: He used to do that to me at Sunday lunchtime.
He used to sit and say all sorts of terrible things eat their dinner.
I mean, he'd put his elbows on the table because we had the kitchen table .
I will have a little piece of that lemon pie.
I'll have a very small piece.
Cos we, at lunchtime we have trays and we have six to a table, we have three up the side and one on the end.
And sometimes it's pretty hard to get the one on the end in because they've, you've got jugs and things, and so you're pushing them all up.
We couldn't get him and he had about this much off.
And he came and he had a massive full plate of rice and curry and then he had custard and gooseberry pie sort of thing.
And he came in and sat down and put his elbows on the edge of his tray and it all went whack over his blazer and it all slid down onto his trousers.
And I was sitting up, up, say this is the head of the table I was sitting where mum is.
And I saw it and everybody in the whole room saw it and burst out laughing cos it was so funny.
What he's going to be a drummer?
You don't have to go to Caterham school to become a drummer.
Do you see that father with long hair and
I should think he's in the group, isn't he?
Oh no, no, Philip's father, no.
He looks like one of the you know
Who was the man that gave the speech?
His old man is, has got long blond hair but he's bald on top
and he wears erm sort of grey cowboy boots.
And he's got a silver guitar on his lapel
I always thought he was a jazz
No he does, he does erm, er oh forgotten what you call it now.
He designs buildings and windows and things.
Well, he's a sort of architect.
He designs certain bits on buildings like arches, and windows and things like that.
He's got a very nice vehicle.
It's like erm a Range Rover isn't it?
So we sat there and we decided he was obviously a musician.
He likes music but he's not a musician.
He looks like and I, first of all when we saw him I thought who the hell is that, can't be a father cos look at him, he looks terrible.

ptr.w: Did he come to the ball?
Did he come to the ball Sue?

s.w: Did you see the one who kept running up and down in the weird hat?
Well that's his, that's his tribal .
He, he is a head of them, he head of the tribe.
One of the main tribes of
They don't call them they call them tribes or whatever it is .
And he er, well he's probably French.
You see his dad is basically a king.
A king, a kingdom, so Richard's really a prince.
Doesn't mean that father of his is a queen does it?
Runs up and down screaming and jumping up and down.
Well when did you see her?
You sort of creep into a corner and hope she doesn't see you.
She's alright to say hello to but then
One of the nicest mums there is.
I think she is too Alex.
You don't actually want to stand next to her though do you?
When I was playing rugby and I hurt my thumb she actually lent me a very expensive Jaeger coat to keep me warm.

vocal.w: She did and I got mud all over it .

ptr.w: you can't stand any too much she's always on the move.

s.w: She comes to all the, all the football.
Yes, she is, she's very nice but you don't actually want to, if you're on the, the touchline you don't want to stand next to her.
Well she's jumping up and down, she's screaming and laughing and shouting at people and hollering oh.
That, that's what she goes there for.
I think the worst thing is when their team at matches.
They were losing and she knew they were going to lose and their last bloke was coming in and she was cheering them on.
Ah we, we, her and I cheered on who, who, who couldn't score, he never, they never got a score.
It was yeah they'd come quite a long way actually.
Oh yeah, hang on, I can't think who they are but they came all the way .
And we're all going out on the field going come on, very good, we're gonna beat your team, and we got our man and we scored about seven tries in the first three minutes.
It's a very rough game Alexander.
Oh they're going to change the rules that erm, you know there's two scrumhalfs start on their side of the scrum, well they can't come round to the other side.
in the centre of the scrum you've half and you've got
So as long as you're behind the ball you can keep moving
Well you, that's what you can do at the moment.
Yeah but the new rules for our age group is you have half of the scrum and then you have the scrumhalf and he puts the ball in and he goes back to his side doesn't he?
And the other scrumhalf and normally the other scrumhalf will come round and tackle him.
Or push him off the ball or something

ptr.w: As long as he stays, stays behind the ball then he's allowed to do that.
Well they're not allowed to, they're not allowed to yeah but they're not allowed to do that any more.

s.w: He can't, so he can't come
And he can't, you can't do twist any more.
The number eight can't pick it up.
And erm I can't remember what the other one is.

ptr.w: Oh you can't push more than one point four metres or something or other.

s.w: Do you take a tape measure with you?

ptr.w: five minute scrum you can't push over

s.w: The reason is you've got to take

ptr.w: take out all the extra sort of strain
All of the extra strain on the

s.w: I suppose the trouble is yeah if you do push, if you do go for that the other side cos you just sort of push them into the

ptr.w: what about when you, what about when you make
Oh as soon as , as soon as you, about over fifteens er is normal rules.

s.w: The good thing about being in the scrum is when you push over and they all collapse and you fall on top of them.
Or you stand there and you walk over them.
Do they get as much pleasure about walking over you?
No cos I normally hit back.
I don't know much about rugby.
Not I'm not very good at it.

vocal.w: Oh I see, as you're no good at it, it's boring.

s.w: No, cos it's, you just watch somebody smack a ball as hard as they can with the one wood and see how far it goes.
But you've got an objective, you've got to get it down a hole .

ptr.w: Yeah, put it in a hole.

unclear.w: look at the money they make, golfers.

s.w: Yeah look at the money skateboarders make.
